On the histograms, the x-axis represents the reaction condition variables, while the y-axis shows the frequency of occurrence of each value interval in the dataset. Environmental Technology Laboratory (LabTAM) Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte Natal RN 59078-970 Brazil In response to the growing demand for carbon-neutral energy technologies, CO2 methanation has emerged as a promising thermochemical route for converting carbon dioxide and renewable hydrogen into synthetic methane—supporting hydrogen storage, energy integration, and greenhouse gas mitigation. However, predicting catalytic performance remains challenging due to the complex interplay between catalyst properties and reaction conditions. In this study, we applied interpretable machine learning (ML) to a curated dataset of 1489 Ni-based catalysts (over 26,000 data points) collected from peer-reviewed literature. Among the models tested, XGBoost achieved the best performance, with R2 = 0.998 (training) and 0.911 (test) for CO2 conversion, and R2 = 0.999 (training) and 0.777 (test) for CH4 selectivity. SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) and Partial Dependence Plot (PDP) analyses revealed key influencing variables, including reaction temperature, Ni content, calcination temperature, particle size, and reduction time. Guided by these insights, two catalyst formulations were synthesized and experimentally validated, with results closely matching model predictions. These findings highlight the potential of interpretable machine learning for guiding rational catalyst design in CO2 methanation, linking data-driven predictions to physicochemical properties that govern catalytic performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 methanation Ni-based catalysts Machine learning Shap analysis Catalyst design Renewable fuels Data availability The dataset and Python codes supporting the findings of this study are available in an open-access repository at https://github.com/lamaramaciel/methanation-code-data. 1 Introduction As the world faces the urgent need to mitigate climate change and move towards a more sustainable economy, developing effective strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions is critical [1]. With atmospheric CO2 levels surpassing 420 ppm and continuing to rise, it is estimated that emissions must be reduced by up to 75 % by 2050 to limit global warming below 2 °C. In this context, CO2 methanation has emerged as a promising thermochemical process for converting carbon dioxide and renewable hydrogen into synthetic methane, suitable for terrestrial applications and even proposed for future extraterrestrial missions. This approach addresses the intermittency of renewable energy sources while maintaining compatibility with existing natural gas infrastructure [2,3]. Additionally, converting CO2 into valuable chemicals, such as higher alcohols, has been identified as a promising route for reducing greenhouse gas emissions [4]. Moreover, CO2 methanation supports hydrogen production and biogas upgrading. Hydrogen, often generated from fossil fuels via steam reforming, contains impurities such as CO and CO2 [5]. Catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to methane helps purify hydrogen streams, enhancing overall efficiency and sustainability [5,6]. In addition, biogas derived from the anaerobic digestion of organic waste contains high levels of CO2 and can be methanated with green hydrogen to produce biomethane [7–9]. This approach contributes to a closed carbon cycle, supporting decentralized energy generation and reducing dependence on centralized energy systems [8,10]. Nickel-based catalysts are widely recognized for their effectiveness and affordability in CO2 methanation [11,12]. However, optimizing their composition and operating conditions remains a challenge due to the complex interactions involved. Traditional trial-and-error approaches are time-consuming and resource-intensive. In contrast, machine learning (ML) offers a data-driven approach capable of identifying patterns and accurately predicting performance from large datasets. This allows for faster, more efficient catalyst screening and design [13–16]. Several studies have demonstrated the potential of machine learning in optimizing catalytic processes. For instance, Song et al. [17] developed an ML model to predict the cumulative methane yield from lignocellulosic wastes, highlighting the importance of features such as lignin content and organic loading. Similarly, Garcia-Escobar et al. [18] constructed a model to predict CO conversion efficiency in water-gas shift (WGS) processes based on catalyst properties and reaction conditions. Their analysis identified potential catalyst candidates by examining variables such as metal type, support material, and preparation method, which significantly influence performance. Another relevant contribution is from Chattoraj et al. [19], who combined theory-guided ML with experimental data to enhance the predictive accuracy of catalyst performance. Their hybrid approach integrated density functional theory (DFT) descriptors into the ML model, improving its ability to predict outcomes for a range of catalyst compositions and conditions. In dry reforming, interpretable ML frameworks have also been applied successfully to predict and validate catalyst performance, demonstrating the capability of such models to handle complex catalytic systems [20]. Despite technological advances, the large-scale implementation of Power-to-Gas (PtG) systems still faces major challenges, including catalyst efficiency, process optimization, and the economic feasibility of hydrogen production, storage, and distribution [2,21,22]. Machine learning can help overcome these limitations by uncovering structure-performance relationships in Ni-based catalysts for CO2 methanation, contributing to more efficient and cost-effective system design. This study adopts a data-driven approach by applying advanced and interpretable ML techniques to address the complexities involved in catalyst selection and optimization. A robust dataset of experimental results was analyzed to develop models capable of accurately predicting CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity while assessing the influence of catalyst properties and operating parameters. Interpretable tools such as SHAP (Shapley Additive exPlanations) and PDP (Partial Dependence Plots) were used to ensure both predictive power and model transparency. Importantly, model predictions were validated through the synthesis and catalytic testing of two Ni-Ce/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, enabling a practical assessment of the ML-guided design approach. The consistency between experimental results and SHAP-identified key descriptors—particularly Ni crystallite size and BET surface area—provides a strong foundation for integrating molecular-level insights into data-driven catalyst design. This comprehensive analysis establishes clear links between catalyst structures and their functional outcomes, contributing to developing more efficient catalytic systems for carbon mitigation and clean energy. 2 Methodology 2.1 Data collect In the preliminary phase of the study, a broad literature search was conducted to gather information from recent publications addressing CO2 methanation using Ni-based catalysts. Although a large number of articles were initially screened, only 55 were manually selected based on data completeness and relevance for modeling purposes. These articles met key inclusion criteria, such as reporting experimental studies on Ni-based catalysts, providing CO2 conversion and/or CH4 selectivity under defined reaction conditions, and clearly describing catalyst composition and process variables. A systematic review was conducted across specialized journals using keywords such as “CO2 methanation AND Ni,” “CO2 methanation AND Ni-based catalyst,” and “CO2 hydrogenation to CH4 AND Ni.” Data were extracted from figures using WebPlotDigitizer software to ensure unbiased retrieval. Selection was driven by the quality and completeness of the data, not by performance outcomes, minimizing potential bias in model training. The collected information was compiled into a structured spreadsheet and categorized into four main groups: 1. Catalyst Composition and Properties: Including Ni content, promoter type and content, and support material. Frequently reported parameters included the specific surface area (SBET, measured by the BET method) and Ni crystallite size. 2. Synthesis Methods: Documenting the preparation approach, calcination temperature, and calcination time. 3. Reaction Conditions: Including reaction temperature, pressure, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV), catalyst reduction temperature and time, and the H2/CO2 ratio. 4. Performance Metrics: CO2 conversion, CH4 selectivity, and catalyst stability were recorded, with CO2 conversion being the most frequently reported metric. 2.2 Data processing Data processing is a crucial step in applying machine learning methods to catalysis. Experimental data are often reported using a wide variety of formats and units, primarily due to the lack of standardized guidelines for data reporting in the heterogeneous catalysis field [13]. This variability requires careful standardization of all descriptors and performance metrics to ensure consistency and reliability in subsequent analyses. All collected descriptors were therefore converted to uniform units and formats. A major challenge involved handling missing data, which was addressed using appropriate imputation techniques to minimize the impact of incomplete entries. This step was essential to preserve the dataset’s integrity and support the effective application of machine learning models. However, imputation was not applied to critical variables such as specific surface area (SBET) and active phase particle size, given their strong influence on catalytic performance. As a result, 361 entries lacking particle size data and 143 entries missing SBET values were excluded. Following this data cleaning process, the final dataset comprised 1041 entries, with all 17 original variables retained, ensuring a robust and high-quality dataset for modeling and interpretation. Furthermore, categorical features such as support type and promoter type were not included as inputs for modeling, due to their limited recurrence and diversity across the dataset, which could lead to sparsity and reduce predictive reliability. 2.3 Descriptive analysis Histograms were employed to evaluate the distribution and range of continuous variables related to reaction parameters. These plots illustrate the frequency of values across intervals, helping to characterize variability and identify trends within key experimental conditions. In addition, donut charts were used to visualize categorical variables, providing a clear overview of the distribution of synthesis methods, supports, and promoters. Together, these graphical tools supported the identification of patterns, asymmetries, and outliers in the dataset. Furthermore, correlations among all descriptors were analyzed to avoid the inclusion of highly correlated variables in the modeling phase, as such variables may be redundant and increase model complexity. Pairwise correlations were calculated using Pearson’s correlation coefficient (PCC), a widely used statistical measure of linear relationships between continuous variables. PCC is defined as: P C C = ∑ ( x i − x m e a n ) ( y i − y mean ) ∑ ( x i − x m e a n ) 2 ( y i − y mean ) 2 In this equation, xi and xmean represent the sample values and mean of variable x, respectively, while yi and ymean represent the sample values and mean of variable y [16,23]. 2.4 Predictive analysis The primary goal of this study was to develop models capable of predicting CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction using experimental data. The dataset was split into training (80 %) and testing (20 %) subsets. Four ensemble machine learning algorithms were implemented and compared: Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGB), Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LGBM), Random Forest (RF), and Gradient-Boosted Decision Trees (GBDT). Their performance was evaluated for both target variables. XGB is a refined version of the decision tree algorithm that employs gradient boosting to improve model accuracy. It is well suited for handling high-dimensional data and is computationally efficient, enabling the development of robust predictive models. LGBM is optimized for performance on large datasets and offers fast training times. RF builds multiple independent decision trees and aggregates their outputs, providing strong resistance to overfitting [24]. GBDT, in contrast, builds trees sequentially, with each new tree correcting the errors of the previous ones to improve generalization [25]. To enhance model performance, hyperparameter tuning was conducted using the RandomizedSearchCV method, with the parameter ranges detailed in the Supplementary Material (Table S1). A 10-fold cross-validation strategy was employed to ensure robustness and prevent overfitting. Prediction accuracy was calculated as the average across all cross-validation folds. As the models employed are tree-based and inherently insensitive to the scale of the input features, standardization or normalization of the continuous variables was not applied. It is important to note that only continuous variables were used as model inputs. Categorical features, such as support type, synthesis method, and promoter type, were excluded from the modeling phase due to their imbalanced distribution across the dataset and limited availability in some studies, which could compromise model generalization.Model performance was assessed using the coefficient of determination (R2), mean absolute error (MAE), mean squared error (MSE), and root mean squared error (RMSE). Higher R2 and lower error values indicate better predictive accuracy. The formulas for each metric are provided in Table S2. 2.5 Causality analysis and partial correlation analysis Improving the interpretability of machine learning (ML) models is essential, particularly when working with ensemble algorithms, which often operate as “black boxes”. To address this, interpretable strategies were implemented, including both model-specific and model-agnostic approaches. While model-specific methods are tailored to particular algorithms (e.g., linear regression), model-agnostic techniques can be applied post-training to any model type [26,27]. In this study, the SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) framework was used to interpret the relationships between input variables and predicted outcomes. SHAP enables both local (instance-level) and global (dataset-level) interpretation by quantifying the contribution of each feature to the model's predictions. Using the best-performing algorithm, the most relevant descriptors were identified through a feature importance analysis—a form of causality assessment. SHAP applies principles from cooperative game theory to assign each feature a value reflecting its influence on the model output, offering a comprehensive and intuitive understanding of variable relevance [20,28]. In addition, two-dimensional Partial Dependence Plots (PDPs) were generated to visualize the marginal effects of key features while holding others constant at their mean values. These plots helped to uncover nonlinear relationships and interaction effects between variables. All modeling steps were performed in Python, using open-source libraries such as Pandas and NumPy for data processing, Matplotlib and Seaborn for data visualization, Scikit-learn for implementing machine learning models, and SHAP for model interpretation. To generate partial dependence plots, the PartialDependenceDisplay library from Scikit-learn was utilized. 2.6 Experimental validation To assess the model’s predictive applicability beyond literature-based data, two catalyst formulations (10Ni1Ce400 and 30Ni1Ce400) were selected for experimental validation. Their compositions were defined based on model interpretation via SHAP and Partial Dependence Plot (PDP) analyses, which highlighted specific ranges of Ni and Ce loadings and calcination temperature as influential for performance. The γ-Al2O3 support was obtained by microwave-assisted combustion using aluminum nitrate and urea, followed by calcination at 550 °C to stabilize the γ-phase. Ni and Ce were co-impregnated via incipient wetness impregnation using aqueous solutions of nickel(II) nitrate and cerium(III) nitrate, with target loadings adjusted by precursor stoichiometry. After drying at 60 °C, the materials were calcined at 400 °C for 3 h. Catalytic activity was measured across a temperature range, and experimental values were compared with those predicted by the ML model. Structural and textural characterization, including XRD, N2 physisorption, SEM, and BET analysis, was performed to ensure consistency with the data domain used for model training. Full characterization details are provided in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Descriptive and statistical analysis A descriptive analysis was first performed on the input features and target variables from the compiled dataset, which included 26,802 data points across 1489 instances. The dataset comprised 13 numerical input variables and 2 numerical output variables. This initial analysis provided insights into the distributions and variability of the data, serving as a foundation for subsequent in-depth modeling. Table 1 presents summary statistics for all features, including count, mean, standard deviation, minimum, 25th percentile, median, 75th percentile, and maximum values. The input variable analysis showed an average Ni content of 15.24 wt %, with values ranging from 1 % to 41.3 %. The specific surface area of the catalysts averaged 231.16 m2/g, ranging from 2 m2/g to 847 m2/g, indicating broad morphological diversity. Promoter content averaged 1.36 wt %, with some samples reaching up to 15 %. Calcination temperatures ranged from 300 °C to 800 °C, with an average of 514.46 °C, and calcination time ranged from 0.5 to 12 h, averaging 3.74 h. In terms of reaction conditions, the average reduction temperature was 541.04 °C (ranging from 300 °C to 850 °C), and the reduction time averaged 2.22 h. GHSV values ranged from 3 to 160 L/gcat·h, with an average of 29.85 L/gcat·h. Pressure was relatively constant at ∼0.14 MPa, and the H2/CO2 ratio averaged 3.92, typically between 3 and 4. The average reaction temperature was 344.91 °C, ranging from 150 °C to 600 °C. Regarding catalytic performance, the average CO2 conversion was 50.39 %, with a standard deviation of 28.73 %, and maximum conversion reached 100 %. CH4 selectivity averaged 90.11 %, with several instances of 100 % selectivity, indicating high efficiency in methane production. The highest CO2 conversion observed was reported by W. Ahmad et al. [29], which explored the performance of the 5 %Pr-12 %Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in CO2 methanation, yielding interesting results. The catalyst demonstrated a high CO2 conversion of 98.2 % at a temperature of 300 °C and GHSV of 6 L/gcat.h, maintaining a constant selectivity of 100 % for methane during a 48-hour stability test. The nickel (12 %) catalyst supported on γ-Al2O3 and promoted with praseodymium (5 %) exhibited a specific surface area of 62.0 m2/g and an average particle size of 14.9 nm. In addition to numerical data, Fig. 1 presents categorical variables related to synthesis methods, support types, and promoters, illustrated through donut charts. These visualizations highlight trends in catalyst formulation and shed light on common practices in the field. Wet impregnation (23 %) was the most frequently reported synthesis method, demonstrating its practicality and efficiency. Incipient wetness impregnation and citrate complexing were also common, especially in promoted catalysts. Less conventional techniques—such as ultrasound-assisted co-precipitation and sol-gel processes—reflect the diversity and innovation in catalyst preparation [30,31]. Alumina (Al2O3) was the most used support (28 %), favored for its chemical inertness and thermal stability [11,32]. Mesoporous materials like MCM-41 and SiO2 also appeared frequently, valued for their surface characteristics and favorable metal–support interactions [33,34]. Regarding promoters, 70 % of the samples contained none. Among those used, Ce and La were the most common, improving catalyst activity and stability by enhancing electronic properties and resistance to sintering and coking [29,35,36]. Fig. 1 also includes histograms displaying the distributions of reaction variables: GHSV, pressure, H2/CO2 ratio, and reaction temperature. Most data points fall within 250–450 °C, a range commonly associated with high CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity. Though less common, some studies explored lower temperatures (starting at 150 °C) using more selective catalysts or three-phase reactors. On the other end, high temperatures often promote sintering and carbon deposition, accelerating catalyst deactivation [29,36–40]. Atmospheric pressure was used in 87 % of the experiments, consistent with conventional setups [37] . An outlier at 2 MPa involved a 10 %Ni-MOF silica-supported catalyst that achieved 77.2 % CO2 conversion and ∼100 % CH4 selectivity during a 52-hour test at 310 °C [41]. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) is another important factor affecting the hydrogenation of CO2 for methane production. An increase in space velocity tends to decrease the conversion rate of CO2 due to the shorter residence time of the reagents on the catalytic surface, reducing catalyst activity [42]. In some cases, a higher space velocity may promote greater methane selectivity, allowing adjustments in reaction conditions to favor selective methane formation over undesirable by-products [43]. Most reported GHSV values were below 60 L/gcat·h, suggesting a preference for lower flow rates. Fig. 2 displays a scatter plot of CO2 conversion versus CH4 selectivity, color-coded by reaction temperature. The plot reveals that higher temperatures tend to cluster with higher CH4 selectivity, reinforcing the influence of thermal conditions on catalytic performance. 3.2 Predictive analysis Before initiating the predictive analysis, the relationships among reaction conditions, synthesis parameters, and catalyst properties were explored. Fig. 3 shows the Pearson correlation matrix as a heatmap, highlighting correlations between dataset features. The matrix uses blue and red shades to indicate negative and positive correlations, respectively, with darker colors reflecting stronger relationships. Correlations above 0.3 indicate weak relationships, while those above 0.7 are considered strong [20]. The feature “Promoter (Z)” which corresponds to the atomic number of the promoter element, exhibited a strong positive correlation (r = 0.81) with “Promoter (wt %)” representing the promoter concentration. Due to this redundancy, “Promoter (Z)” was excluded from model training and testing to avoid multicollinearity and enhance model reliability and generalization [44]. Moderate correlations were observed, such as 0.35 between calcination temperature and both Ni content and promoter loading, suggesting a possible influence of calcination on metal dispersion. A correlation of 0.33 between calcination temperature and catalyst surface area also indicates that thermal treatment may impact textural properties. Most other features showed weak or no correlation, indicating independence among descriptors. This research aimed to develop and evaluate predictive models for CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity using four different machine learning algorithms: Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGB), Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LGBM), Random Forest (RF), and Gradient-boosted Decision Trees (GBDT). The dataset was split into 80 % for training and 20 % for testing. All models underwent hyperparameter tuning and k-fold cross-validation to ensure robustness across data splits. Among the algorithms evaluated, XGB delivered the best performance on both training and test sets. Ten-fold cross-validation was used during hyperparameter tuning to avoid overfitting and improve generalization. Table 2 summarizes the models' performance metrics, including R2, mean absolute error (MAE), mean squared error (MSE), root mean squared error (RMSE), and mean accuracy. XGB achieved the best results, with an R2 of 0.9980 (training) and 0.9113 (testing) for CO2 conversion, and 0.9999 (training) and 0.7769 (testing) for CH4 selectivity. These values confirm the model’s strong generalization ability, further supported by cross-validation results, with average training accuracy of 0.8936 for CO2 conversion and 0.8011 for CH4 selectivity. The higher MSE and RMSE values in the test datasets are attributed to the inherent complexity and variability of catalytic systems, along with the presence of outliers. Variables such as active phase particle size, promoter content, calcination time, reduction time, GHSV, and pressure exhibited wide distributions, contributing to larger prediction errors. Additionally, the diversity in catalyst composition, preparation methods, and operational conditions across studies introduces further modeling challenges. Despite these limitations, the XGB model demonstrated excellent robustness, with lower MAE values and higher mean accuracy, confirming its capability to handle complex, heterogeneous datasets. The Supplementary Material includes scatter plots comparing actual and predicted values for both targets (Figures S1 and S2), offering visual validation of model performance. XGB outperformed the other models, but RF, GBDT, and LGBM also showed competitive results. RF achieved an R2 of 0.9921 (training) and 0.8563 (testing) for CO2 conversion, although its CH4 selectivity prediction was slightly less accurate. GBDT delivered performance similar to XGB, with a test R2 of 0.9120 for CO2 conversion, confirming its potential. LGBM, while slightly less accurate than XGB and GBDT, still provided acceptable results, particularly for CO2 conversion. These performance differences underscore the complexity of catalytic systems and the importance of selecting the appropriate algorithm based on the prediction objective. Despite the use of regularization and cross-validation, a mild overfitting was observed, particularly for CH4 selectivity. This may be partially explained by the highly skewed distribution of this target variable (75 % of the values ≥ 97 %), which limits variability and reduces generalization capability. Moreover, the lack of standardized reporting in the literature, such as active site quantification, time-on-stream performance, or catalyst–support interaction details, may introduce hidden biases. Similar performance drops between training and test sets have been reported in other ML studies based on literature-derived catalytic datasets, including those focused on biomass higher heating value [45], lignin depolymerization [46], CO2 adsorption [47] and multimetric optimization in photocatalysis . These cases reinforce that moderate overfitting does not preclude the extraction of meaningful insights for catalyst formulation and experimental prioritization. 3.3 Causality analysis To better understand the factors contributing to the superior performance of the XGBoost (XGB) model in predicting CO2 hydrogenation to methane, the SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations) methodology was employed. This approach enables a detailed interpretation of the relative importance of input descriptors in the XGB algorithm, identifying the most impactful variables influencing the model's output. Fig. 4a and c display bar charts that visualize the mean absolute SHAP values for each variable, reflecting their average contribution to the model’s predictions for CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity, respectively. Higher SHAP values indicate greater influence on the model’s output. Reaction temperature emerged as the most significant variable, with mean SHAP values of +18.55 for CO2 conversion (Fig. 4a) and +3.53 for CH4 selectivity (Fig. 4c). This strong positive contribution confirms that higher temperatures enhance both conversion and selectivity, in line with studies reporting faster reaction kinetics and improved surface activation at elevated temperatures [48]. As temperature increases, more energy becomes available to overcome activation barriers, accelerating the formation of methane. However, excessively high temperatures may also lead to catalyst deactivation or activate undesired pathways such as the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction [49], which competes with methanation. Specifically, temperatures above 450 °C have been associated with increased CO formation and reduced methane yields due to the prevalence of RWGS [3]. This behavior reflects thermodynamically favorable pathways and greater activation of surface-bound CO2 species, which are closely tied to the molecular-level restructuring of the active phase under thermal stress. The active phase particle size emerged as a key variable, ranking second in importance for CH4 selectivity and fourth for CO2 conversion, with mean SHAP values of +3.46 and +3.78, respectively. Smaller Ni particles generally provide higher surface area and more accessible active sites, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Recent studies have shown that ultrafine Ni particles (∼1.2 nm) exhibit remarkable H2 adsorption capacity and catalytic performance, while moderately sized particles (∼8 nm) also contribute positively due to favorable surface crystallography and metal–support interactions [50–53]. These observations highlight the critical role of morphological control in maximizing catalytic efficiency in CO2 methanation. Nickel (Ni) content was another highly influential descriptor, with average SHAP values of +4.54 for CO2 conversion and +2.35 for CH4 selectivity. Literature reports consistently demonstrate that higher Ni loading enhances CO2 conversion, particularly in alumina-supported catalysts [54–56]. This is attributed to Ni's role in facilitating C–O bond cleavage and subsequent hydrogenation to CH4. While low Ni contents often lead to increased CO formation, higher loadings favor methane production [52]. On a mechanistic level, Ni loading also governs the density of active sites and the degree of metal dispersion, both of which influence the formation of Ni ensembles essential for the methanation pathway. Other features, including specific surface area (SBET), calcination temperature, reduction time, and promoter content, also contributed significantly to the model's predictions. Following the analysis of the bar charts summarizing mean absolute SHAP values, beeswarm plots (Fig. 4b and d) were evaluated to investigate how individual feature values influence model predictions across all samples. While the bar charts offer a global view of variable importance, beeswarm plots provide instance-level insights, showing the distribution of SHAP values for each feature. In these plots, the y-axis lists the input features, and each point represents the SHAP value of a feature for a given sample. Red points denote higher feature values, and blue points represent lower values, while the x-axis indicates the direction and strength of each feature’s contribution to the prediction. For CO2 conversion (Fig. 4b), the most influential variables were reaction temperature, Ni content, active phase particle size, specific surface area (SBET), and calcination temperature. These features displayed broad SHAP value distributions, indicating a variable impact across different samples. A concentration of red points at high SHAP values for reaction temperature confirms its strong positive influence, consistent with the dataset’s temperature distribution—approximately 58 % of the samples are in the 250–450 °C range, typically optimal for methanation [37,38]. Lower temperatures (blue points) were associated with negative SHAP values, reflecting reduced predicted conversion rates. This supports the conclusion that a moderate thermal input is essential for effective CO2 methanation. Similarly, higher Ni content and reaction pressure were linked to positive SHAP values, indicating favorable contributions to CO2 conversion. In contrast, the influence of promoter content showed mixed behavior, with both positive and negative SHAP values depending on the sample, suggesting that promoter effects are highly dependent on their chemical nature and concentration. For CH4 selectivity (Fig. 4d), the most impactful features were active phase particle size, reaction temperature, reduction time, SBET, and Ni content. In general, higher values of these variables correlated with increased SHAP values, and thus higher predicted selectivity. Notably, small Ni particles (blue clusters with high SHAP values) were associated with enhanced CH4 selectivity, while larger particles and longer reduction times corresponded to lower SHAP values, indicating diminished selectivity. While reduction time had limited impact on CO2 conversion, it emerged as a key factor for CH4 selectivity. The broad spread of pink points along the SHAP axis suggests that longer reduction times negatively influenced selectivity. This trend is supported by literature reports, which indicate that prolonged reduction can weaken metal–support interactions and decrease Ni dispersion, resulting in larger metallic domains and lower catalytic performance [57]. Calcination temperature also significantly affected catalyst performance, consistent with recent studies [58,59]. For instance, Wang et al. [59] systematically evaluated the role of calcination temperature in shaping the performance of Ni/CeO2 catalysts for CO2 methanation. Their results showed that increasing the calcination temperature enhanced metal–support interactions (MSI), which in turn improved Ni dispersion and reducibility. These effects contributed to greater thermal stability and overall catalytic activity. At optimal temperatures, a more uniform distribution of Ni particles was achieved on the CeO2 surface, promoting both reactivity and durability. However, the authors also identified a critical limit: calcination above 700 °C favored the formation of nickel silicates, which are difficult to reduce and exhibit low CH4 selectivity. This trade-off highlights the importance of precisely controlling thermal treatment to maximize catalytic potential. Beyond its influence on activity and selectivity, calcination temperature also strongly affected textural properties such as Ni crystallite size and BET surface area. Bamatraf et al. [58] demonstrated that well-regulated calcination prevents Ni particle sintering and agglomeration, thereby maintaining high surface area and active phase dispersion. These structural features directly impact the number of accessible active sites, ultimately improving catalytic efficiency in CO2 methanation. These insights are further corroborated by the SHAP dependency plot (Figure S3, Supplementary Material), which illustrates the interaction between calcination temperature and Ni content. The model predicts that high Ni loading combined with elevated calcination temperatures (∼700 °C) leads to lower SHAP values, indicating a negative effect on CO2 conversion. Conversely, high Ni content coupled with moderate calcination temperatures enhances model performance, suggesting that balancing metal loading and thermal treatment is critical for optimizing dispersion, reducibility, and reactivity. Interestingly, the specific surface area (SBET) displayed a general trend of negative SHAP values. While high surface area is often desirable in catalysis, excessively large SBET values may reflect poor pore connectivity or unfavorable adsorption dynamics, which can restrict access to active sites and lower catalytic efficiency. In some cases, diffusional limitations or site deactivation may also arise in materials with overly large surface areas, complicating the relationship between surface area and catalytic performance. Other process-related features, such as reduction temperature, calcination time, GHSV, and reaction pressure, showed variable influences across the dataset, reflecting the multivariate complexity of heterogeneous catalysis. Their impact depends on the specific combination of parameters and catalyst structure in each sample. In summary, SHAP beeswarm plots provided valuable insight into how individual variables impact the model's predictions for both CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity. The combination of global and local interpretability enhanced the understanding of catalyst performance, offering practical guidance for the rational design of Ni-based catalysts. The interpretability of the model strengthens its utility in real-world applications, bridging the gap between data-driven predictions and catalytic design strategies. 3.4 Partial correlation analysis To gain further insight into the interactions among key descriptors and their influence on CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity, Partial Dependence Plots (PDPs) were generated. This approach enables the visualization of the marginal effects of specific variables, including reaction temperature, calcination temperature, Ni content, reduction time, and active phase particle size, on model predictions. The analysis focused on PDPs depicting Ni content against the three most influential variables identified in the SHAP analysis for both CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity, aiming to identify parameter combinations that maximize catalytic performance. For CO2 conversion, several important interactions were revealed. As shown in Fig. 5a , reaction temperatures above 300 °C generally enhanced conversion, especially when Ni content exceeded 15 wt %. At lower Ni contents, conversion improved only at higher temperatures, typically in the 400–450 °C range. These results underscore the need to balance metal loading and thermal input to achieve efficient performance. Additionally, Fig. 5b indicates that calcination temperatures below 500 °C are associated with higher CO2 conversion, whereas temperatures above 600 °C, particularly when combined with low Ni loadings, result in poorer performance. This is consistent with SHAP results and highlights the detrimental effect of excessive calcination on catalytic activity. Furthermore, Fig. 5c shows that particle sizes below 15 nm, when combined with high Ni content, significantly improve conversion, while larger particles (>30 nm) with low Ni concentrations correlate with lower conversion efficiency, emphasizing the importance of tailoring catalyst morphology [56,60]. Supporting these observations, Supplementary Figure S4f shows that the combination of low calcination temperatures and small particle sizes (<30 nm) yields improved CO2 conversion. Similarly, Figure S4c associates calcination below 500 °C and promoter content in the range of 1–10 wt % with enhanced performance. These trends reinforce SHAP-based conclusions regarding the synergistic impact of thermal treatment, metal loading, and promoter concentration. Moreover, low GHSV values (5–40 L/gcat·h), especially when paired with high Ni content (>15 wt %), are likely to improve conversion by increasing residence time and facilitating reactant access to active sites. For CH4 selectivity (Fig. 5d–F), the PDPs suggest that optimal values are achieved with Ni contents between 10–30 wt % and reaction temperatures ranging from 350 °C to 450 °C. High selectivity also correlates with reduction times below 2 h and particle sizes under 30 nm. In contrast, Figure S5i reveals that extended reduction times (>3 h), combined with larger Ni particles (>30 nm), lead to diminished CH4 selectivity—consistent with previous reports linking long reduction periods to particle sintering and performance decline [57]. These findings confirm that short reduction times and well-dispersed small particles are key to enhancing methane selectivity, while prolonged treatments may induce metal agglomeration and reduce efficiency. Overall, the PDP results corroborate the SHAP analysis by offering a more nuanced understanding of variable interactions. Together, these tools provide a solid foundation for rational catalyst design and process optimization, ultimately guiding the development of more efficient Ni-based systems for CO2 methanation. 3.5 Experimental Validation of Model Predictions To validate the machine learning model beyond the literature-derived dataset, two catalyst formulations, 10Ni1Ce400 (10 wt % Ni, 1 wt % Ce, calcined at 400 °C) and 30Ni1Ce400 (30 wt % Ni, 1 wt % Ce, calcined at 400 °C), were synthesized and tested. These compositions were selected based on Partial Dependence Plots (PDPs), which identified intermediate-to-high Ni content (10–30 wt %), low Ce loading (≤1 wt %), and low calcination temperatures (∼400 °C) as optimal for high CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity. The catalysts were prepared via incipient wetness impregnation of a γ-Al2O3 support synthesized by microwave-assisted combustion, using nickel(II) nitrate and cerium(III) nitrate as precursors. After impregnation, the materials were calcined at 400 °C for 3 h. Catalytic activity was evaluated over the 300–550 °C range by measuring CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity at each temperature. Although long-term stability tests were not performed, data were collected after signal stabilization at each temperature point, following standard procedures for reactivity screening. Fig. 6 compares model predictions with experimental performance. For 30Ni1Ce400, the model accurately predicted the maximum CO2 conversion (72.8 % at 340 °C) and the sustained high CH4 selectivity. The 10Ni1Ce400 catalyst also showed strong agreement with predictions across most temperatures, except for a sharp decline in CH4 selectivity above 540 °C. This deviation likely results from the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction, which was underrepresented in the training data [61,62]. Additional characterization provided in the Supplementary Material confirmed the structural and textural coherence between the synthesized catalysts and the model-based predictions. X-ray diffraction (Figure S6), N2 physisorption (Figure S7), SEM (Figure S8), and textural properties (Table S3) further support the model’s robustness. These findings strengthen the molecular interpretation provided by the SHAP analysis and confirm that structural descriptors, such as metal crystallite size and surface area, are not only statistically relevant but also chemically meaningful within the catalyst design framework. While the validation confirms the model’s predictive capability, discrepancies at high temperatures emphasize the need to expand the dataset to include conditions where side reactions (e.g., RWGS) become significant, thereby improving prediction accuracy across broader catalytic regimes. 4 Conclusions In this study, interpretable machine learning techniques were applied to a comprehensive dataset compiled from the literature to investigate how process parameters and catalyst properties influence the performance of Ni-based catalysts in CO2 methanation. Four advanced models (RF, GBDT, LGBM, XGBoost) were developed and evaluated, with XGBoost demonstrating the highest predictive accuracy, achieving R2 values of 0.9980 (training) and 0.9113 (testing) for CO2 conversion, and 0.9999 (training) and 0.7769 (testing) for CH4 selectivity. Partial Dependence Plots (PDPs) further revealed that optimal catalyst performance is associated with moderate reaction and calcination temperatures, specific Ni concentrations, and suitable reduction times. These findings emphasize the complex interplay between catalyst composition and operational conditions and provide guidance for targeted catalyst design. The study also demonstrated the feasibility of developing highly selective methanation catalysts by tuning key variables such as Ni content, particle size, surface area, calcination temperature, and reduction time. These descriptors, especially Ni crystallite size and BET surface area, were not only statistically relevant but also chemically meaningful, aligning with known structure–activity relationships in heterogeneous catalysis. The resulting models revealed structure-property relationships that complement experimental and theoretical efforts in catalyst development. Such insights offer a mechanistic rationale at the molecular scale, enhancing our understanding of how specific structural features govern catalytic behavior. A key limitation of this work is the distribution bias within the dataset, which affects the model’s generalization across the full range of conditions. Regions with low reaction temperatures (below 250 °C), high calcination temperatures (above 700 °C), and elevated pressures (above 1 MPa) are underrepresented. Although synthesis method and promoter type were not used as input variables, their limited diversity in the dataset reflects a narrow formulation space. These imbalances may have contributed to the lower predictive performance observed for the CH4 selectivity model. Expanding the dataset to include more diverse formulations and operating conditions will be crucial to improve model robustness. Overall, this work highlights the potential of combining chemistry, materials engineering, and data science to accelerate the development of Ni-based catalysts for CO2 methanation. The identification of critical variables lays a solid foundation for future efforts aimed at optimizing catalyst formulations and advancing energy and environmental technologies. coredata.dc:description: In response to the growing demand for carbon-neutral energy technologies, CO2 methanation has emerged as a promising thermochemical route for converting carbon dioxide and renewable hydrogen into synthetic methane—supporting hydrogen storage, energy integration, and greenhouse gas mitigation. However, predicting catalytic performance remains challenging due to the complex interplay between catalyst properties and reaction conditions. In this study, we applied interpretable machine learning (ML) to a curated dataset of 1489 Ni-based catalysts (over 26,000 data points) collected from peer-reviewed literature. Among the models tested, XGBoost achieved the best performance, with R2 = 0.998 (training) and 0.911 (test) for CO2 conversion, and R2 = 0.999 (training) and 0.777 (test) for CH4 selectivity. SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) and Partial Dependence Plot (PDP) analyses revealed key influencing variables, including reaction temperature, Ni content, calcination temperature, particle size, and reduction time. Guided by these insights, two catalyst formulations were synthesized and experimentally validated, with results closely matching model predictions. These findings highlight the potential of interpretable machine learning for guiding rational catalyst design in CO2 methanation, linking data-driven predictions to physicochemical properties that govern catalytic performance.
